reviewText:
Great game to waste time on from driving around, blowing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• up and collecting things. Though extremely repetitive, this has kept me entertained for 90+ hours. (and over 150+ hours on the free multiplayer mod)

PROS
+ HUGE world map; we're talking 400 sq. miles (20 miles x 20 miles)
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=560068093
+ Great graphics (esp for 2010) that still hold up a half-decade later
+ Most PC's can easily handle this; a $100 GPU will max it out at 60 fps
+ Lots of mods available
+ JC2MP, which adds much more things to do (and is free / 30mb)
+ Blowing up ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• is fun
+ Lots of vehicles to utilize
+ Perfect Draw Distance; you will always see the entire world!
+ Nice weather system
+ One of the best Sandbox games out there
+ Affordable; 15$ normally; 2~5$ on sale

CONS
- Extremely repetitive; you're basically just blowing up stuff for most of the game
- Dialogue / Missions are cheesy / bad
- World is far from ugly / barren, but there's few secrets / interesting points of interest
- Driving isn't the best
- Combat can get out of hand fast
- Little to do outside chaotic acts

This game will run very well on most computers as long as they have some power. If you can play CSGO at all you can play this. I have a lower mid-range PC (GTX 750 Ti / crappy old 3.0 Quad core AMD) and I have this maxed out at 60 fps at 1080p

If you love sandbox games this is a must-have, especially if it goes on sale.

Overall, a B+ ~ A- game; it's a must-have for any sandbox fan.

reviewText:
Open-world action game as it should be. Just Cause 2 has that great feeling of absolute freedom - go anywhere, drive anywhere, fly anywhere! You can get to any place on the huge map in just few seconds, you can be defeated without any penalties - this game is here to entertain you, not to blow your mind or make you angry at your keyboard.

Two unique devices underlying the awesomeness of Just Cause 2 are grappling hook and infinitely respawning parachute (infinitely resp...? aw, forget it). Tons of fun guaranteed! Every action game should have it - I really missed them in Far Cry 3. ;-) It brings so much variety and joy in moving and fighting that you'll be travelling for hours here and there just to use them again and again.

The world is really good. Yes, most of the cities and villages are copy-pasted, but there are so many different regions on the map with different climate, weather and views that you'll never get bored. Graphics is on the level too, especially fire and explosions - you'll get addicted to blowing things up! Story and quests are not the strongest part of the game, but they do their job. Another feature worth mentioning is the hidden items' search radar - in my opinion, really great idea. It is finally interesting to find stuff by yourself without spending hours in vain or using guide from the Internet.

There are some cons, of course. Enemies respawning out of nowhere behind your back can be really annoying sometimes. Weapon arsenal is not so big, besides, the lack of ammunition for some weapons leaves you with even less choices. Main story is very short and optional quest lines are not so long either. But there are many things to do on the map - different challenges, races, liquidation contracts... Finally, there's still (and I guess it will be there forever) a bug that prevents you from getting the cherished 100% completion of the game (by the game's internal statistics, not the Steam's one). Thankfully there's only achievement for 75% completion, so no worries, achievement hunters - you'll get your perfect Steam game. ;-)

If you like free roaming in beautiful open-world game, spending time in parachute challenges, races and outpost fightings, searching for hundreds of collectibles and upgrades, spreading chaos by blowing stuff up or just flying around and enjoing you freedom - you'll definitely love Just Cause 2.

reviewText: Just Cause 2 is ridiculous in the best possible way. In the space of a few moments, you can grapple to a hovering helicopter; beat up the pilot and hijack the chopper; blow up a cluster of fuel tanks; put the chopper on a collision course with an enormous antenna; jump out at the last moment; and watch the resulting explosion as you parachute down to the saddle of a moving motorcycle below. But in the life of Rico Rodriguez, such events are just another day at the office, though in this case, the office is the gigantic island nation of Panau, where three gangs vie to wrest control from a corrupt government. This is a big game that gives you a lot to do and a lot of crazy ways to do it. When Just Cause 2 gives you the freedom to do the things you want in the way you want, it shines in all its preposterousness and good humor. When missions and challenges shoehorn you into specific actions, however, the same loose mechanics that make the open-world exploration such a joy become a frustrating burden.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Just Cause 2
Original Release: 2010
Genre Tags: Sandbox; Action; RPG; Third-Person; Open World
My Overall Grade: A
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 15-50 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary (Standalone)
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Sandbox gamers
REVIEWBlow up a small fishing village's water tower in order to save their country. Why? Just 'cause.

Just Cause 2 is one of the best games around for exciting open-world mayhem. Nice graphics and animations, a diverse gameworld, and an interesting atmosphere establish an enjoyable explorative experience. The world is loaded with collectibles to find, vehicles to commandeer, and things to blow up. And it is headlined with exciting, distinctive gameplay chock-full of mayhem and destruction. If you are into sandbox mayhem, this should be a sure thing for you; and even more casual fans of the genre should easily enjoy this game too, because it is just so outright fun.

Now Just Cause 2, as is apparent by the title, is the sequel to the first Just Cause game. The first game was decent, and I had some fun playing it. But to be honest: anything it can do, this can do better. Both games use the same core concepts for gameplay, except the ideas were certainly executed better in Just Cause 2. So you really don‚Äôt have to worry too much about missing anything worthwhile if you would prefer skipping over the first game entirely. Even the narrative of Just Cause 2 is almost entirely unconnected to the first game‚Äôs story, so reading a brief synopsis should be more than sufficient for you to fully enjoy the experience. Having said all of that, though, if you really enjoy the genre, then you may want to check out the first game too.

Anyway, the strongest attribute of Just Cause 2 has to be the riotous gameplay. You move around in an over-the-shoulder view while on foot, with various firearms at your disposal for taking out militants. And the patented grappling-hook mechanic allows some innovative ways to take down foes, bringing a distinctive novelty to the combat. Furthermore, shortly into the campaign, a wide variety of vehicles (cars, boats, helicopters, planes, and more) becomes available. These are great not only for your basic traveling needs, but also to perform ridiculous and hilarious stunts. And of course, the grappling-hook and parachute combination can be used to explore the gameworld in the signature Just Cause fashion that affords the franchise its unique identity. And with the myriad of collectibles to find, structures to destroy, statistics to record, and achievements to unlock: there is no shortage of things to do.

And I suppose if the gameplay is the best attribute of the game, then the gameworld presentation is a very close second. The graphics are pristine and the landscape is packed with diverse sceneries and environments. From mountain peaks to desert valleys, it has it all. The animations and effects are also mostly well designed, which enhances the gratification of bringing a wake of destruction through every last place you visit. And the world is humongous. Even with a jet it can take a while to cross the map. Luckily there is a fast travel system that allows you to begin a sky-dive from above any location you have visited. It integrates perfectly with the game, taking what would be tedious and flipping it into one of the most enjoyable things to do. Just Cause 2 easily has one of the most entertaining gameworlds to explore.

But even with all of this going on, the game starts off with a very focused and linear mission that allows you to be introduced to the main narrative elements of the campaign. You will come to find, however, that the story aspects of Just Cause 2 are minimal, and mostly mediocre. So you definitely shouldn‚Äôt go into it expecting to be told an elaborate story. But despite that, the narrative flows and the various missions are certainly enjoyable. The missions are purposeful and focused, which can be a refreshingly stark contrast to the mindless mayhem side of the game. But while there is a decent amount of total missions including the extras, there are very few main storyline missions, which does hold the overall experience back a bit. So there is some room for improvement.

Ultimately, Just Cause 2 is a good example of what can be done in video games when great concepts meet great execution. It is such an all-around fun and distinctive experience that I would recommend everyone give it some consideration; and if you are a fan of the genre, then it should be a no-brainer.

And as an addendum: there is now a free multiplayer mod DLC. With the mod, the opportunity for hilarious stunts and mayhem is increased exponentially as numerous players can all play in the same sandbox at once. As a free bonus, it is a pretty sweet addition and can be a lot of fun if you like that kind of thing. Luckily, if it doesn‚Äôt sound like your thing, it is also easy to completely ignore since the mod installs as a separate ‚Äúapp‚Äù on Steam with separate statistics and achievements tracking.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 gives you a massive island nation to freely explore, wreaking havok as you slowly discover hundreds of locations and find over a thousand items. JC2 is so insanely fun because it completely indulges the player while minimizing the tedious elements of open world games.

Other open world games require slow walking, but JC2 gives you over 50 vehicles (cars, tanks, fighter jets, and more) plus your essential grappling hook and parachute. If you‚Äôre hoofing it, you‚Äôre doing it wrong. Rather, open up the anywhere-accessible black market and buy a helicopter with dual-machine guns.

JC2‚Äôs biggest achievement is how it makes you feel totally in control, able to go anywhere and do anything. There are no invisible walls or disconnected ‚Äúlevels‚Äù. And visually, JC2 is really, really attractive. The weather and water are standouts still looking good years after release. The artwork is all very well-crafted, with amazing attention to detail.

The story is fun, too, with a very B-movie feel, intentionally hokey, but it works very well because of very solid voice work. The game also has a great self-awareness, featuring a hilarious dictator who will make you chuckle as he spouts his pontifications from loud speakers.

Are there downsides? A few. You run out of ammo often, but after 5 hours or so you learn to simply order new guns. There‚Äôs no stealth elements but that‚Äôs ok. Very few buildings have accessible interiors but no biggie.

Overall, the large scope, consistent quality, and accessible controls of JC2 make it one of the purest video games ever created. When you‚Äôre tired of ‚Äúserious‚Äù games let JC2 cleanse your gaming palette.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is a legendary over the shoulder sandbox shooter along the lines of Grand Theft Auto without the charm. The game focuses on destruction, deep controls and doing whatever craziness you'd like to do. You play as Rico Rodriguez and you've been sent in by the government to mess things up like a kitten in tissue paper on an island nation that seems giant by gaming standards. You have the option work for different factions / gangs that have their own agendas. The gangs are a nice touch and you'll see them battle each other on the island while civilians run and hide. Its a nice AI dichotomy.

Since the game is set on a bunch of giant islands, the terrain is gorgeous and diverse. You'll see lush green jungles beneath icy mountains, then go into those icy mountains and down into sandy deserts. After that, you can take a boat for a ride across beautiful blue waters, then hijack a jet and surf on top of it into a golden sunset while dodging missiles. Everywhere in this game is a gorgeous place and there are tons of places to visit and blow up. There doesn't seem to be any interiors, but that is fitting for a game so beautiful with good traversal diversity.

The controls are deep, but they allow you to do a lot more than your average over the shoulder sandbox shooter. You have your standard, run, jump, gunfire, reload, grenade, toggle guns, toggle grenades buttons, but you also have the infamous grapple hook. This hook is what the Bionic Commando reboot was missing. Double pressing it will send you instantly zipping to wherever it latched onto. Traversal is made super easy, climbing up buildings with the hook, but not just that, but you have a parachute that is used to glide around. Simply hit the jump button while in the air to deploy the chute. Pressing and holding the grappling hook will grapple something, but then when you hold it, aim at something else and release the button, you've now tethered two things together, which results in hilarity. Tether a moving car to the ground, to watch the car flip over. Tether a NPC to a rocketing propane tank and watch them blast off. Not just that, but there is plenty of car combat. Normal games would have you just get in a car, not this game, you can get on top of the car to shoot things, or you can slip down in front or behind the car to shoot things using the car for cover as its moving. You can take over moving vehicles, with easy quick time events that show a struggle instead of just kicking a person out from behind the wheel.

Combat is pretty easy, you just aim the cursor and fire. There is no aim button, if your cursor is remotely near anyone or anything, you will see a red highlight around the logical target. So if you the player have terrible aim, Rico Rodriguez will still shoot the target. In terms of holding guns, you can hold one two handed gun and two one handed guns. There are throwable explosives and you can toggle between two types. You can also melee enemies with the grappling hook.

With so much control freedom, you can tackle missions any way that you want. Such as a car chase mission where you need to escort the driver, do you grappling hook vehicle to vehicle, taking out enemies and struggling to knock out the driver? Do you tether the other vehicles to the ground and watch them crash, or do you use your parachute to hover over the action and blow up the other vehicles? The choice is yours. It is an excellent game to do what you want.

Missions themselves give you easy to follow objectives as if they were steps to follow. Open the gate, take out that rocket launcher, take out those snipers, pick up that item, grapple onto that helicopter, and so on. The objectives are marked with red and easily found with how far away they are. If you try to deviate too far from a mission location, the game will warn you and start a 10 second counter. This keeps the intensity on and prevents people like me from exploiting things.

Outside of missions, there are plenty of things to do and they're all marked on your map. Well you need to visit the location marked on your map before you find what it is there to do. Things such as races, time trials, destroy bases and loot villages. Destroying locations and looting villages each has a percentage attached to it. To loot a village, you need to find 100% of things hidden there. Things like vehicle parts, weapon parts, cash boxes and even liberate the village from propaganda buses. Thankfully when you get near something findable, it will show up pointing out where you are, but you need to be very near it. This saves you from detailed searching. It is the same for ammo boxes and health cabinets.

As for the bases, you need to find things and blow up things such as towers, generators, gas tanks, communication towers and surface-to-air missile launchers, each will make up 100%. It is fun for explorers to seek out every nook and cranny, but I can understand if getting 100% would feel like a chore.

When you create chaos or break any sort of law, the local military will be sent after you. At first it'll be simple things hunting you down, but if you keep creating chaos, your 'heat' level will go up and more soldiers will come after you. How do you reduce your heat level? Hide. Yep hide in the jungle and after time your red heat will go to orange heat and start dropping down. This is good for keeping the focus on what you were doing before you created heat. With plenty of jungle in the game, it is pretty easy to ditch any heat you might have.

Sadly the enemies feel pretty dumb. No one takes cover when you're putting bullets into them, even if enemies are next to cover, but I guess people play for the fun of doing what they want, not the challenge. In car chases enemy vehicles will just ram other objects. It leads to some laughable moment. They'll just drive off cliffs when you hit the brakes. I can understand scripted events like running into a gas station, but otherwise it is hilariously bad.

The game is pretty easy even on normal with regenerating health. Not just that, but health pickups from cabinets seem well placed. If you die, you go to the last checkpoint. Sometimes the checkpoints are further back than you think, but that's the only thing that really presents a punishment in the game.

The real downside to the game is that it seems to crash once every few hours back to the desktop. Luckily the game has an autosave feature.

To top all of that off, there is a free Multiplayer MOD that allows every player into one world together for chaos to ensue. Is it worth $15? Sure.... but it has been on sale before at $2.50. Keep that in mind.

reviewText:
This game is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing insanity. From the ridiculous story, to the mechanics, to the all-out action, to the cheesy characterisations, this game is 100% ludicrous good fun.

It's at its best when you're in the middle of the action with explosives and vehicles erupting left right and  centre - there is certainly no shortage or vehicles, weapons, explosive tanks, and enemies to engage with. Do you want to surf a 747? You can. Do you want to fly as high as possible and then just skydive for a nice 5 or 6 minutes? You can. Do you want to hijack a chopper mid-air and use it to destroy an oil refinery just for the thrill of it? You can. This is up there as one of the most fun sandbox games to date.

Unfortunately, however, the world is pretty shallow, and for all the locations and collectibles, the breadth of the gameplay is fairly limited. It's not a living, breathing world like the GTA worlds - the environment (which looks wonderful and varied enough in terms of climate and locations) is inhabited by people without personalities, and who exist only to be shot at, blown up, or otherwise maimed. The missions are compelling to a degree, although there is a degree of repetition in the faction missions that would become grating if the action wasn't so fun. However, I didn't at any point on XBOX or PC find myself compelled to 100% the game, as this involves hours of repetition with little tangible reward. This is felt the most when the end-game is at hand, and there's not a lot to motivate you to play beyond the completion of the missions.

The story isn't very compelling or coherent, but it is bad to the point of *almost* coming around to good again, of which credit should be given to the writers for just going with it (a climactic battle that happens while clinging to a ballistic missile in flight?!). However, the dialogue itself is pretty bland and boring, and the sense of humour that they're going for doesn't always hit the mark.

In summary, the JC2 is huge and stunningly beautiful, and the action is ever-present and very fun, which makes this a vast improvement over its predecessor, and lets it stand apart from the other open-world games of its time. In saying that, it lacks the personality of the world that GTA nailed, and the sense of humour that Saints Row did so well, which leaves it feeling comparatively empty at its core. However, if you're looking for spectacle, the game is well-priced and looks amazing, and there's a lot you can do and see in this game that can't be found elsewhere.

For the price, I highly recommend it.

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is a 2010 open world action-adventure video game developed by Avalanche Studios, published by Eidos Interactive and distributed by Square Enix. It is the sequel to the 2006 video game Just Cause.

The player is free to roam the game's open world, not having to focus on the game's storyline. Progress in the game is measured with Chaos, which is earned by completing missions, destroying government property, collecting items for the factions and reaching 100% completion in settlements and military bases. Chaos unlocks new agency missions and stronghold takeovers. Chaos and stronghold takeovers expand the factions' area of influence, which unlocks faction missions and race challenges.

Initially, the player must acquire weapons and vehicles in the field. Early in the game, the player encounters a black market supplier, from whom weapons and vehicles can be purchased, with an option to have them delivered to the player's location via helicopter. As more Chaos is gained, additional weapons, vehicles, and the extraction option become available on the black market. All weapons and vehicles on the black market have parameters that can be upgraded in several steps, by building upgrades with weapon and vehicle components found within the game world. There are over 2,000 parts that the player can acquire.

Overall by my experience, this Game is a Must-Have so I would Rate it:

Rate 11/10

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 takes place in South East Asia on the Panau islands. You play the role of a man named Rico Rodriguez sent to track down a dangerous American. However, in order to get the information you need you work with the 3 rebel/criminal factions, the Reapers, the Roaches and the Ular boys against the country's oppressive government.

Just Cause 2 is a beautiful game, sure, but looking back I honestly would want to take the over 100 hours I spent on completing this game to 100% back. It's a grind fest, all Just Cause 2 consists of is collecting weapon parts, vehicle parts and destroying a number of things to reach 100% completion in any given settlement. There isn't very much replayability once you've completed every settlement to 100%.

Aspects of Just Cause 2 Worth Praising
‚óè Destructive environments. The majority of trees and shacks in the environment will come tumbling down if you use explosives or crash into them with a vehicle.

‚óè Creative transportation. The idea of using a parachute while using your grappling hook to slingshot your way across the landscape it quite creative and exclusive to Just Cause 2. I often find this method of transportation superior to using conventional land vehicles.

‚óè Plenty of vehicles to drive! Cars, bikes, atvs, boats, helicopters and planes are all in this game.


Aspects of Just Cause 2 Worth Criticizing
‚óè No licensed music. You often take licensed music in other open world games for granted but after playing through Just Cause 2 for over 105 hours, it makes you realize that it's the only thing keeping you sane. It couldn't have cost that much to license music from obscure artists or at least implement a feature where you can manually install music tracks and listen to them through your PDA while you're zipping around Panau, could it?

‚óè Horrid voice acting. It's debatable but it can only be seen clearly if you have experienced a multitude of other products to compare. Personally, I see it better than Ride to Hell Retribution although Bolo Santosi and the npcs you have to escort through stronghold take overs are the cringe worthy.

reviewText:
*WARNING: The following review contains plot spoilers to a 5-year-old game.*

One of the most fun sandbox shooters of our time. Ridiculous action sequences, over-the-top explosions, and lots of angry Pinoy infantry.

The Gameplay is split up between freeform exploration including cars and bikes, planes, boats, helicopters and skydiving (with unlimited butt parachutes for paragliding purposes, complements of Uncle Sam) and a little bit more structured missions with objectves that need to be checked off before the mission can proceed towards completion. How you go about these objectives (neutralize targets, rescue VIP's, capture locations or vehicles) is often left up to you, provided you don't stray too far from a designated mission area. Weapons are multitudinous and varied; your standard assault rifles, pistols and submachine guns as well as rocket launchers, grenades, triggered explosives, and the more exotic hookshot weapon which allows you to attach opponents to the ceiling, a vehicle, or each other, as well as move around quickly in both horizontal and vertical movement.

The Story revolves around Rico Rodriguez, spy and mercenary hired by the US (off the record, of course). Your job: Cause chaos and destruction across the tiny island nation of Panau, whose new president Baby Panay (Yes, seriously) has started to isolate the nation and build up the Panauan military. This has caused the purposely nebulous Agency to be called in, to destabilize the nation and install a puppet for a head of state. It is all utterly ridiculous, stock Bond novel stuff with lots more explosions and thankfully less Bond-babe-bedding. The fact that all of this terrorism carried out in the name of the US turns out to all be because of the newly discovered and massive Panau oil fields, leaves a bad taste in my mouth. All of that blood on your hands, and it was simply to protect national fuel interests.

In Conclusion

Play this game:
* If you're looking for a fun, light, free-form experience
* For the flying mechanics
* Because explosions.
* For the graphics. Visually, this game is a marvel. Prettiest environments and ambient effects in any game of its generation!

Don't play this game:
* For the story. So asinine, so childish, so ripped from better sources
* For the voice acting. Egregious examples: Bolo Santosi, Tom Sheldon and military radio ops.
* If you like a challenge. As a long-time casual" player
date: I find most missions a breeze right up until the end\n* For the missions. Where the game really shines is freeform exploration and combat. Clear out a base

reviewText:
IntroductionJust Cause 2 is an amazing, open-world sandbox-esque game with breathtaking visuals and massive explosions to boot. This game takes a lot of what makes a game like Grand Theft Auto good, adds a grappling hook, and puts in much more destruction into the world. If for some reason you're getting this game instead of Just Cause 3, then you're still going to have an awesome time.

Please note that I have played this game for quite a long time before I owned it on Steam so my hours do not match up with my actual game time.

Gameplay
Story
You are Rico Rodriguez, your typical badass gun with a gun (and a grappling hook). Set after the events of the first game, you're essentially trying to overthrow this evil dictator and confront your old mentor. I'll state right off the bat, that the first game sucks, and the story in the first and second games sucks as well. Where the GTA series has had a pretty good storyline, Just Cause didn't get that bit right yet. You are likely not going to be very interested in the story if at all, and it's fairly tedious to do the missions for reasons I'll explain later on. On the off chance you do like the story, there are some interesting missions and places you have to go, which are honestly pretty fun. But just know, the story isn't the selling point of this game.

Combat & Exploration
What you will most likely play Just Cause 2 for, is the insanely explosive combat, and the highly immersive, open world that it provides. From the open seas, to densely populated towns. From the cold mountain peaks, to the warm valleys below; this game has it all. I've played countless times just simply free-roaming and admiring the beauty of every environment. But what's a beautiful environment without some kick-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• explosions am I right?

Just Cause 2 features a variety of weapons and vehicles at your disposal. Simply order a drop from your handy black market supplier, or raid a base and steal all their weapons and grab your favourite car from anyone you see. The choice is yours. Combine all this with your multi-use grappling hook, and you can quickly imagine all the possibilities in game. Don't like a soldier looking at you funny? Hook him to your car and take him for a ride. Need a lift? Hook your car to an airplane before it takes off. Two guys, one gun? Hook them together and let the magic happen itself. :^)

My only concern with the weapon/vehicle system was that it felt a bit difficult to acquire the exact weapon/vehicle you wanted. The drop system was very expensive and income was very slow. For a sandbox style game, it felt very anti-sandbox to have those limits in the game. Just Cause 3 has fixed this issue. But don't let that deter you, there is a lot of raw fun to be had in this game, and you'll spend hours in it just trying out everything your mind can imagine.

Multiplayer
Most people play the multiplayer mode, which is a free DLC to obtain on Steam. If you thought single-player was fun, you're definitely going to love multiplayer. It's everything in single-player multiplied by the number of players in the game.

VisualsFor a game released in 2010, Just Cause 2 is beautiful. The graphics hold up extremely well and even surpass a lot of games that are out right now. It's very well optimized and will run on almost anything that isn't over 2 years old at this point. Explosions are stunning, while skydiving gives you the sense of speed that it should as you plummet into the earth/sea at super high speeds, only to pull your parachute at the last second and admire the spot where you would have died instead.

AudioMusic is okay, sound effects are pretty great, voice-overs suck. Much of the audio isn't really the selling point of Just Cause 2. I feel like there could have been more here, but at least the sound-effects carry it most of the time. You'll be entertained quite a bit, but you may notice that there is definite room for improvement.

SummaryJust Cause 2 is one of the best games of its time, and is still insanely fun even now. Its graphics hold up extremely well and has one of the largest game maps in existence. Whenever you tire of playing alone, the free multiplayer dlc will add countless hours of fun once again, and will lead to some of the best moments in gaming. Despite a few sub-par aspects of the game (story, voice-acting, etc), this is a game you will have endless hours of fun in, and you'll barely remember anything negative about the game.

If you like a really good open-world game with super-fun gameplay, look no further than Just Cause 2.

9/10 - Must buy.

reviewText: The story and voice acting is tripe, but answer me this ... what other free roaming sandbox game allows you to skyjack a military jet and surf on the nose cone?  Just Cause 2 is a beautiful, fun and surprisingly well optimized rampage through a massive world that easily puts even MMORPGs to shame.  You can go anywhere, steal anything and the destruction of both property and watching a car you just tethered to a windmill as it tumbles through the air is beefy and satisfying.  The grappling hook in the game is easily the best tool in gaming since HL2's Gravity Gun, if not better.  It aids in traversing terrain easily, providing a ride when combined with your unlimited stunt parachute, or in combat with clever, hilarious ways using classic grappling, or tethering two things together, including people.  I highly recommend this game for its fun and destructive escapism, but if you're the type of person who can't enjoy a game without realism, you'd better just continue being boring.

reviewText:
I never got around to play the original Just Cause. Mainly because my computer has always had issues with it, and Just Cause 2 pretty much improves the first game in all levels. Just Cause 2 is a third-person action game, and when I say action game I mean crazy jumping-from-airplanes-and-blowing-up-cities - sort of an action game. Rico, the protagonist, is like James Bond on steroids. You can pretty much do whatever you want, in a world at least twenty times (!) bigger than San Andreas, and five times bigger than World of Warcraft.

Pick your vehicle; helicopter, airplane, sports car, moped, tuk tuk etc. and pick a random location; beach, jungle, city, highway, mountain etc. to ram, stunt, blow up, crash, projectile etc. with it. Or just hook yourself to someones boat and enjoy the eyecandies of this tropical paradise. Or hook the same guy's boat into an airplane, and see him take off. Or hook the airplane to a skyscraper and see it torpedo into a ball of flames. Your choice.

The grappling hook, amongst other things, is what lift this game up from the pleasant, boring and realistic open-world games. You can use this Godly thing to pretty much survive any situation. Are you falling from insane height? No problem, just hook towards the ground and survive - Or just precipitate your parachute, that works too. It lacks actually physics though, you can't use your hook to decapitate moped drivers for example, a feature that I would want for Just Cause 3!

Sure the game is far from being realistic and serious, but with great looks, insanely huge map and more vehicles and weapons than you can count - who cares if it's unrealistic? You can stand on a plane while towing another one mid-air, for God's sake! I completely recommend this title if you are even remotely intersted in action, open-world and/or just plain time-consuming roaming and freedom. There is currently a third-party mod in the works, adding Multiplayer. It adds a whole new meaning to the already balls-chaotic world, and makes it go beyond the edge.

Pick this game up, if you have not already! It's been on a billion sales.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is one of the most enjoyable games I‚Äôve ever played, with nearly every piece of this game resonating with me on some level. From the narmy, b-movie aesthetic with stereotypical characters who love nothing more than to chew the scenery and a plot that seems like it was lifted directly out of a James Bond rip-off; to a stunningly beautiful, gargantuan tropical paradise to explore and destroy at my own pace; and finally to the ludicrous over-the-top action that unfolds at every single skirmish, this game left an indelible mark on me that few games have come close to matching.

While the game‚Äôs story is about as shallow as it comes and lasts for only a handful of hours if you really wanted to push through the story, that‚Äôs not where the game‚Äôs fun lies; exploring, experimenting, and eradicating all that stands in your way at your own pace is the true joy. The game is absolutely massive; it will be dozens of hours before you even came close to completing a mere half of the map. Unfortunately, you may find this tedious after a while as many of the bases and villages are duplicates of each other. Thankfully, each quadrant of the island has a different aesthetic to it, from the sweltering, arid deserts to the bustling metropolitan areas to the snow-capped mountains to the tropical shores, the nation of Panau seems to have a little bit of everything. This will help to take the tedium out of the game.

You will be wanting to spend time on this island, too. I cannot stress how wonderful and truly massive it feels; clocking it at roughly four hundred square miles, Panau is easily the largest world I‚Äôve ever seen in an action video game. And while the visual style is not photorealistic, it does an absurdly exceptional job at creating a sense of scale. When skydiving for the first time, I was breathtaken at how small I felt in relation to the rest of the world.

This feeling will never quite go away, even after hundreds of skydives. You will be doing a lot of skydiving; the parachute and grappling hook was my de-facto method of map traversal. It is a ludicrous way to travel in a ludicrous game; the larger-than-life action will be sure to excite. You can creatively destroy all that stands in your way through a combination of traditional weapons and vehicles to some non-traditional gadgets, such as the aforementioned grappling hook and some special secret agent toys to pilot and shoot. Shooting out tires, tethering enemies to moving cars and rockets, C4 detonations, and high-speed car chases where you rapidly negotiate your way around several still moving cars will become the commonplace.

While the paper-thin excuse plot and repetitive nature of the game may leave a bad taste in many players‚Äô mouths, I believe that the gorgeous environment and exciting action as well as the ability to set your own pace means that this game has definitely become one of my favorite games of all time.

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/lbwg_8slXqU
Game: Just Cause 2
Genre: Open World Third-person Shooter
Developer: Avalanche Studios
Publisher: Square Enix
Copy supplied by Steam

Just Cause 2 is an open world action game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Square Enix in 2010. This is the first of many reviews to come about the latest installments of franchises that are coming back in the near future.

STORYYou play as Rico Rodriguez, one of the Agency's main operatives, as he is sent to the island of Panau to oust Panay from office, as well as track down and assassinate his old mentor, Tom Sheldon, who the Agency fears has gone rogue after disappearing during the regime change. In order to find Sheldon, Rico allies himself with the three dominant criminal gangs on the island: the Roaches, an organized crime syndicate, the Reapers, an insurgent Socialist militia and the Ular Boys, an ultranationalist rebel group that espouses traditionalism and opposes foreign influence.
The story is over-the-top and the dialogue is really cheesy. The story serves only to justify you being a terrorist who destroys power plants, ventilation systems, dams, military bases and many more objects. Save for a few moments in the 7 Story Missions, it is not memorable.

GRAPHICSEven though it has been 5 years since the game was first released, it still looks damn great on PC: the island is colourful, the explosions are vibrant, the draw distance is long and the water feels realistic. The only things that have always been the problem with the game are the facial textures and animations. Other than that, you will have a gorgeous experience that will run at 60fps even on a toaster.

GAMEPLAYThe goal is to cause as much chaos as you can by destroying military facilities and everything related to that. Right from the get-go you can explore the 400 square miles of Panau, discovering the 368 locations, engaging in high-speed chases by water, plane or car, hijacking enemy vehicles to crash into oil rigs... There is a lot of variety in what you can do and how.
The big game changer is the grappling hook, which can be used to gain speed while using your unlimited parachutes, to pull enemies from ledges, to attach a speeding vehicle to the ground so that it flies in the air, to attach an enemy to the ceiling and turning him into a human pi√±ata, and so on. You can also carry three weapons (two sidearms, one big gun) and both grenades and sticky bombs.
There is the black market, which can be used to order and upgrade weapons and vehicles, or as a way to fast travel. But I strongly recommend that, because each time that you go from one place to the other, you are bound to find an hidden collectible, a new location, or a new badass vehicle that you hadn't tried already.
The side activities that you complete for the gangs are very similar to one another, and usually consist of escorting someone, finding an object in a base or destroying a base or two. There are also races that are varied and very fun to play.
The game is a ton of fun, and you won't regret the time you'll spend with it.

CHALLENGEThe game tends to be very challenging even on the easiest settings, thanks to strong and numerous enemies that will pursue you, as well as an unforgiving checkpoint system in the missions.

SOUNDThe soundtrack is hugely underrated, but really strong and energizing, while the voice acting is one of the cheesiest since the original Resident Evil. But since it seems like they made that on purpose, I'll let it slide.
The sound effects are great, with clear distinctions from one gun to the other, and with some hugely satisfying explosions.

REPLAYABILITYA huge map, tons of collectibles, multiple missions and 50 Steam achievements are bound to make you play this game for a long time to come, especially if you are waiting for Just Cause 3's release.

Overall, this is a phenomenal game to play, with an amazing open world, fluid and varied combat, multiple collectibles, strong soundtrack and beautiful vistas. This is a game that I love, and I strongly recommend buying to everyone who loves action games. Glory to Baby Panay!

IT'S GOOD
You, agent Rico Rodriguez, have the task to find and kill your old friend and mentor. He's missing in the island paradise Panau. To find him, destroy as much as you can. (Don't as me why. I understand it neighter)

Just Cause 2 you're a nice open world game with awesome action, sounds and visual effects - but you are not a story game!

++ BIG OPEN WORLD (more than 300 places to discover)
++ fast travel
++ nice vehicle variation (cars, trucks, boats, airplanes, jets...)
++ very good sound
++ the explosions are really breathtaking
+ many challenges, group missions or objects to find
+ lots of funny moments
+ no hard achievements
+ MULTIPLAYER - could be funny with friends (didn't played it yet)
+ Just Cause
+ You are like Spiderman with your hook
+ It will take some time to complete all achievements (~ 40-50 hours)

- 7 main missions? C'mon! That's nothing!
- you don't play this game for the story, don't forget it!
- short playtime for the main missions - 8 to 10 hours if you rush
- AI enemies are easy to beat
- some of the controls are...sh*t
- I don't like Spiderman

If you look for a very wide open world with a huge variety of weapons and vehicles - This is your game! You don't play Just Cause 2 for the story - you play it for the explosions and the really big world. If you can get it in a sale you can't make something wrong!

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is published in the year 2010 by the Eidos Interactive and it's the direct Sequel to Just Cause.Like it's Prequel,Just Cause 2 is an Open-World 3rd-Person-Shooter/Action Game.

This is going to be a List of Pro's and Contra's about the second Game.

Before i start,i highly recommend an XBOX-Controller! It fixes all Stearing Issues,even planes are awesome to play with it!!!

Pro:
-The Game has a HUGE(1000 square kilometres),beautiful and open Map.
-The Story isn't innovative,but pretty funny and well made.
-The Main Character is a cool,badass Agent who's always up for a Joke(ALWAYS!)!
-There are tons of different Vehicles,from boats to cars,from helicopters to airplanes!
-The controls are really easy to learn,after 10 minutes everybody should be able to play like an expert!
-You can have it for 15‚Ç¨(About 20 Dollars!),and EVERYBODY has do admit that this is a hell of a low price!
-You can waste hours just by running over the map and don't even start the Story(except for the first 2 Missions)
-The Plane/Helicopter controls are awesome(except for the Si-47 Leopard Fighter Jet!)

Contra:
-The car/bycicle controls are not really good,only a few vehicles have good controls!
-The Missions get boring after a while because they are always the same.

So these were all the Points i had to say about the Game,and in my Opinion,it is definitely a Game everybody should own or at least had played it once!It is really fun,and it doesnt gets boring even after reaching 100% because of the huge Mod Community!

I hope i could help you Guys with this Review!

A definitve must buy if you can forgive the sometimes repetitive gameplay.

reviewText:
A really awesome Open-World Game, what can kick the a*s of GTA.

Pros:

- Unrealistic and fun Physics make the game amazingly enjoyable.
- Parachuting and slingshotting are going to be your main transportation and the scenery is gorgeous enough that you don't mind.
- The Game is massive, taking 15-20 min. minimum to get from one side to the other.
- There are a vast amount of cities and many things to blow up and/or collect in them.

Cons:

- Rico can survive giant falls or enormous explosions, but if he is shot more than 3 times he will be near death. Thus making the combat in the game tiresome and irritating at times, seeing as you'll find your self sprinting for cover or looking for a health pack on a building more than you will be actually fighting.
- Missions are redundant stronghold missions play out the same almost all the time, escort technician/demolitionist to point B, right off the bat the gate is down in the stronghold gotta open before you can proceed. Always ends in you protecting the technician from a barrage of enemies ending in the stronghold commander.

SO much fun. Just Cause 2 is the definitive throw-things-down-a-mountain simulator.

I originally bought JC2 at full retail price on Xbox 360 after playing the demo for around 4 hours. It is one of the few games from recent memory that left me with no regrets of paying full price. The open world sandbox is mind blowingly massive and the amount of things to blow up is just mental. Combine that with the crazy gravity defying grappling hook+parachute traveling mechanics and not only is it a vast world but it‚Äôs enjoyable to traverse.
I purchased the PC version solely for mods (infinite grappling hooks, multiplayer, etc.) and while I certainly wouldn‚Äôt drop another 60 bucks on it, the upgrade in hardware plus the ability to mod the game made the purchase well worth while.

reviewText: When I was a little kid, I used to watch a cartoon called Rocket Power.  My favorite character in the show was Twister, for his great haircut.  I was always so inspired by the show that I too decided to ride skateboards in the skatepark.  I went out and spent $700 on buying different wheels for my skateboard, and ended up choosing the one's that were blue, for they were my favorite color at the time.  I threw out the rest of the wheels and headed for the skatepark that was located about seven miles from my house.  It was a long walk, but I knew it would all be worth it.  After my arrival, I headed up for the biggest ramp and made my first attempt.  I fell face first because I didn't put the wheels on correctly and my nose cracked and was bent in the wrong direction.  There was blood gushing everywhere and I thought I was going to die.  I was unable to see out of my left eye, so I thought something had happened to that as well.  Some kid came up to me and pulled out his cell phone and started to dial 911.  An ambulence soon arrived and I was taken to the emergency room.  At this point, I had passed out, but was told the rest of the story.  I had a broken nose and my left eye was dangling out of my head by it's optic nerve.  The doctors at the hospital placed my eyeball back in place without any hygenic precautions.  Once it was back in place, it was soon discovered that there was multiple infections, and that I would have to have my eye removed.  As of today, I have a disformed nose and only my right eye.  However, Just Cause 2 is good, and you should buy this game.

One of my favourite free roaming sandbox games.
If Far Cry 2 and GTA IV had a baby with glorious five-o-clock shadow it would be this game.

So much to do, hundereds of locations to discover and conquer, thousands of things to blow up with your extensive arsenal of weapons and vehicles (Land, Water, Air, but no Fire 0/10 would not bend)

Multiplayer is pretty fun, but I honestly have put around 45 minutes into it.

Controls can be a little wonky if you're used to third-person games on console (like me)

Overall I'd give it 9/10 because the voice acting isn't really my cup of tea and some things can get a little repetitive.

reviewText: I've played Just Cause 2 originally on xbox 360 and put more than 20+ hours into it. Panau is a big beautiful island with lots to see and as Rico AKA The Scorpio as your tour guide. Rico is a mercenary looking for someone on the island and is drafted to help local gangs reign chaos in an attempt to complete his own personal mission.\n\nJust Cause 2 follows somewhat of a GTA game play scheme. Notable differences include driving and the obvious attachment of a hook shot / grapple. This grapple is what makes Just Cause, Just Cause. This thing can literally attach to anything within a certain distance. This includes automobiles, helicopters, buildings, boats, trees, mountains and literally anything you can think of. Upon grappling onto a car, Rico can perform stunt jumps" in which he is able to maneuver himself on and around the car. This comes handy in case you are being fired at and need some extra cover. When attaching oneself to a helicopter
date: Rico can chill underneath or just like a car
recommended: attempt to hijack it. There are a few QTE (quick time events) that need to be performed in order to successfully high jack any moving vehicle. You can also grapple enemies if you're really feeling it. Alternatively
hoursPlayed: Rico can attach his grapple to two objects. Say you want to shoot at an explode-able object but it's not quite close enough to the enemies. Rico can shoot his grapple at the barrel and then attach it nearby or on the enemy. Once the barrel is shot and starts flying

reviewText:
A just cause of 'just because'.
One of the classical overly-explosive action games, this game is a great throwback to the old 80's Rambo-esque movies and mixes traditional third person destruction derby with open world (group of islands) adventure. A tropical GTA of sorts. The basic gameplay consists of destroying evil goverment's property, i.e. water and fuel supplies in random villages, races with every medium possible and both storyline and faction quests. As mentioned earlier, this game embraces the goofy righteousness and lets you wreak havoc upon both the goverment and its civilians with little difference.

Technically this game is a port from original PS3 game, but from my experience it runs great. Even on my laptop I had stable performance on lower graphical settings and the game looks still fantastic for a game of its age (in my mind that's yesterday).

The positive points of this game lie in it's great map design, freedom of gameplay done right (main story is there to create atmosphere and not to restrict features) and a certain kind of 'comfyness' if you're weird enough to get nostalgic about games of this era. (I could also talk about personal experiences I have when this game came out and I played a ton of it w/ my friend but buzzwords are way cooler.) I think Just Cause 2 does what it does so well that I'm probably never going to buy another game that tries to accomplish the same. (For me this is a big deal, especially since the third part of the series just came out)
There aren't much negative stuff for me to say. The game has it's bugs and flaws, but for me it would be such a nitpick on stuff that didn't affect my experience. It does what it promises well, but for people who want a more sensible plot and structural gameplay this might be a short experience.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is all you could want in an open world island adventure. You star as Rico Rodriguez, a man with the task of assassinating his former mentor who has turned crazy. Along the way you will meet several groups of revolutionary armies, such as the Reapers and the Ular Boys, who will send you on missions to hack military bases, takeover strongholds or assassinate colonels. The game is fast-paced and action packed. The main highlights of the game I found were the grappling hook and parachute. Rico is equipped with these from the get-go, and aiming at a certain spot on the ground with the grapple will send you flying off into that direction. Together with the easily deployable parachute, you hardly need cars to travel around the island of Panau.

A minor downside to this game is the loading times. You will be left waiting awhile before entering the world, but is all worth it once in. One feature that is very helpful is the addition of the Black Market. Call for a chopper if you need weapons, vehicles or need to be flown to any previously discovered location (very helpful for Stronghold Takeovers). There are not an excessive amount of weapons in the game, ranging from the light and common pistol and submachine gun, to more powerful guns like shotguns and detached mounted guns (with insanely helpful infinite ammunition).

There are also a large array of vehicles available to steal and hijack, from the cheap rusty Tuk-Tuk all the way up to the Chevalier 999. You can also find tanks, fully loaded with unlimited ammo of guns and autocannons, as well as helicopters and planes with the like.

Overall, Just Cause 2 is an aesthetically astounding, open world adventure, and Avalanche Studios has done an amazing effort at pulling off a gaming spectacle. If you like a game where one minute you are parachuting out of the sky and next minute you are speeding down the deserted Panauan highway with the cops on your tail, this game is for you. The amount of things to do and see are amazing, and I thoroughly enjoyed this game and will be playing it for a lot more hours to come.

reviewText:

This game is exceptionally well optimized as well. It runs on almost any machine with a decent frame rate, and adapts to any resolution flawlessly.
My only gripes are that the gameplay gets a bit repetitive after finishing the main story, but if you are good at making your own fun and are willing to download a few mods, you can enjoy this game for a long, long time.
8/10

However, I can say with 100% confidence that it is the most fun open-world game I have ever played in my entire life. Just Cause 2 holds this high honor on my personal favorites list for a number of reasons:

2. Just Cause 2's selection of vehicles is extremely eclectic, and all of the cars, boats, planes, motorcycles and helicopters are insanely fun to use. My personal favorite is the DLC addon Tuk-Tuk Boom-Boom."

reviewText: Just Cause 2 is probably one of the most eye catching action sandboxes going; thrust into the large sandbox of Panau by parachute you are the stereotypical CIA one man wonder weapon which will tame the hostile regieme for good old uncle sam. But in honesty you do not buy Just Cause 2 for its depth, but rather for the action, the carnage, the pretty explosions, and the pleasant vistas of Panau itself. In many respects Just Cause 2 builds on the premise of Mercenaries and Mercenaries 2; joinable factions, main story missions, side missions, supply drops, vehicle drops, weapon upgrades and the ever present regieme installations, bases, airfields and towns that can be taken one at a time. Either going in solo or working for the various opposition factions does make you feel like you are toppling the regieme one satisfying step at a time. Also be pleasantly surprised by excellent frames per second on the highest of graphics settings; one of the most visually stunning yet stable platforms made for the PC.

reviewText:
This game pushes the limits of open world sandbox games. The map is absolutely enormous and beautiful. Each terrain (dense jungle, desert, frozen mountains, ocean, urban) are expansive and fun to explore.
The missions in the game are fairly brief, and can be beaten in a day. Despite this, you can still put hours into this game with just exploration. There is also a multiplayer mod in development that adds a whole other level of fun.
This game is exceptionally well optimized as well. It runs on almost any machine with a decent frame rate, and adapts to any resolution flawlessly.
My only gripes are that the gameplay gets a bit repetitive after finishing the main story, but if you are good at making your own fun and are willing to download a few mods, you can enjoy this game for a long, long time.
8/10

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 may not be my favorite out of the games that reside in my library, that title is reserved for The Binding of Isaac. However, I can say with 100% confidence that it is the most fun open-world game I have ever played in my entire life. Just Cause 2 holds this high honor on my personal favorites list for a number of reasons:

1. Just Cause 2's world is breathtakingly beautiful. In my opinion, this makes it superior to any of the Grand Theft Auto game worlds, as they are gritty and urban, while the fictional Asian island of Panau is filled with lush tropical landscapes, barren deserts, and even snow-covered mountains.

2. Just Cause 2's selection of vehicles is extremely eclectic, and all of the cars, boats, planes, motorcycles and helicopters are insanely fun to use. My personal favorite is the DLC addon Tuk-Tuk Boom-Boom."

3. Just Cause 2's selection of weapons is also extremely eclectic and each weapon is fun to use. Tearing apart the Panauan military (and helpless civilians) is ceaselessly satisfying and feels like playing a zany action movie akin to Machete or even Tropic Thunder.

4. Just Cause 2's missions are reliably fun. Some of them may be somewhat generic

reviewText:
Graphics are impressive for how well the game runs, as it can easily run on mid-tier systems.
The gameplay is very fluid, featuring a run-and-gun system like Saint's Row, but with a lot of freedom for movement with the almighty grapple (and accompanying parachute). The map at times feels almost TOO big for the amount of content availible on it. Driving cars, just like Saint's Row 4, is horrible in terms of feel, but thankfully there's almost no reason to have to drive a car. Voice-acting is really horrible in terms of believability but is alright in terms of fidelity. The story is pretty empty and gives you no incentive to really play it for the sake of the storyline. The value of this game has greatly increased since the multiplayer mod is availible on Steam.

TLDR; Good gameplay, Bad storyline/VA.

The DLC is garbage and I wouldn't recommend that anyone gets it.
The base game is like $2.99 when it goes on sale, so it's definitely worth it then.

reviewText:
This game is, in my opinion, the best one available for PC, although I have a limited frame of reference. It's not overly violent - or at least if you choose for it to not be. You are rarely outright forced to kill anyone, although it is sometimes the easiest route. However, lots of the missions are very repetitive, but the best one is stealing an armored car and pretty much destroying a highway with it before giving it to the gang who sent you. This could be my definition of a perfect game, if a few things were changed. First off, my definition of a perfect game would be an open world parkour-integrated stealth game with many options for how to go about things, with an engrossing but quick-moving story line (and an epic soundtrack). This game is obviously open world, and it's got very good combat mechanics, even though I generally don't like TPS games. It can be played with a stealth style, but the extremely OP minigun can be fun if you feel like taking the direct route. I almost always take a stealth route because it makes the game more fun. There are some parkour elements, but really not enough to satisfy what I like. Vehicles are very fun to drive, it's one of my favorite things to do. The story could be better, but I'm easily entertained by game's stories, so I find it good. It is, however, a very, very slow game. You have to blow a lot of stuff up to progress, and if you're like me and you want to explore everywhere, it can take you a while to do anything. For example, right now I have 20 hours logged and 11% progress. (In game, not achievements.) Moving on, the map is wonderful. The only thing that really bothers me is the inability to go in any large buildings. That's the only way this game could really improve a lot. The graphics are beautiful, especially for a game that's (I think) 3 years old. Often when I'm playing I'll take a screenshot of Rico floating over a mountain range at sunset, because the game really is that beautiful. Honestly this game is very good looking, and performance is suprisingly good. On my laptop (Basic stats: Intel Core i5, Intel Integrated Graphics, 6GB RAM, and 7200 RPM hard drive) the game runs around 30 fps, although battery life is pretty much instant death. 30 fps may not sound that great, but really I don't even notice it. It doesn't affect how well I play the game, so I don't bother with it. The only time I've ever noticed lag is during cutscenes, when the audio and video get seriously out of sync. Oh well. Soundtrack is well done too.

--Summary--
Pretty freaking amazing. 10/10.
99/100 for not having enough parkour and no going inside buildings.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 pumps you into action the moment the game starts and barely is there time to catch your breath as you go from one area to the next, one plane to the other, one seaboat to another and one parachute to the other. With new enemies, weapons, and vehicles, the game gives you an array of items at your disposal... yeah, well, good or no?

The guns are pretty weak as the realism doesn't set in in this game at all, which is expected considering that's just how the game is meant to be, which is pretty great at times. The game does get repetitive somewhat quickly after about a day's worth of gaming. Only 'specialty' areas are unique, though not in large numbers. Enemies remain the same, without much difference in them and aren't memorable. Same characters as in Just Cause but with, of course, Baby Panay and his men and a few others. Vehicles are nice, nothing special (probably intentional), and easter eggs are plenty, though a rather obvious one is one a lot of people know about whether they've played the game or not or have seen what the egg is referencing.

So, yeah, weapons are meh-y, vehicles uneventful, enemies boring, and locations repetitive.

But does that make it a bad game? NOPE. It's fun, yes, but as the review states here and there, it does get repetitive, but the non-stop action and hilarious ways to kill enemies makes the game quite addictive. Overall, gameplay to 100% completion takes about... well, maybe 80 hours if you play it casually but non-stop probably less. Is it worth doing new games on it? Maybe more-so after a long time of not playing just to be nostalgic.

What this game offers over other games of similar style is... well, the style. Infinite parachutes, grappling hook for every occasion, and a kickass Rico makes the game all the more fun. So go ahead and get it, it's fun and addictive but you shouldn't be expecting to want to play it every waking moment after the first few hours.

7.5/10

reviewText: There really isn't much I need to say about this game. I've sunk hours in on console and on PC, and it is a fantastic open world game. People are going to compare it to Grand Theft Auto, of course, and while in some areas you can, you really can't in others. reviewText:
Just Cause 2 brings much needed improvement upon the first game's format. Improving in almost every conceivable way, it turned a game which was riddled with problems and a repetitive nature into an enjoyable experience. It's far from perfect, story falling into the stupid and cliche once more, but at least somewhat satirical this time, if it was meant to be taken seriously then the voice acting certainly didn't help. Just Cause 2 can also crash on systems well above recommended requirements albeit rare.

Besides those points, there's a lot to like. The soundtrack is better than ever and perfect for the game. Graphics are great and polished, assuming you can overlook the forced depth of field (developers please stop this.) The world is expansive yet detailed with various areas like mountain regions, cities and deserts to explore and complete. Quality of gameplay as a whole has improved drastically with better controls, intuitive combat including use of grapple, better side activates, missions and creative bosses.

Avalanche studios put real effort in between JC1 and 2 and it shows. It's a much more enjoyable game, sure it can be repetitive going for 100%, but I still got a solid 18 hours out of the game without completing it fully. So I recommend picking it up for anyone interested in an open world sandbox all about causing chaos then go for it.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 brings much needed improvement upon the first game's format. Improving in almost every conceivable way, it turned a game which was riddled with problems and a repetitive nature into an enjoyable experience. It's far from perfect, story falling into the stupid and cliche once more, but at least somewhat satirical this time, if it was meant to be taken seriously then the voice acting certainly didn't help. Just Cause 2 can also crash on systems well above recommended requirements albeit rare.

Besides those points, there's a lot to like. The soundtrack is better than ever and perfect for the game. Graphics are great and polished, assuming you can overlook the forced depth of field (developers please stop this.) The world is expansive yet detailed with various areas like mountain regions, cities and deserts to explore and complete. Quality of gameplay as a whole has improved drastically with better controls, intuitive combat including use of grapple, better side activates, missions and creative bosses.

Avalanche studios put real effort in between JC1 and 2 and it shows. It's a much more enjoyable game, sure it can be repetitive going for 100%, but I still got a solid 18 hours out of the game without completing it fully. So I recommend picking it up for anyone interested in an open world sandbox all about causing chaos then go for it.

reviewText: Wanna blow lots of stuff up? Like Asian (or Latino) accents? Then this is a game for you. Just Cause 2 is a TPS (third-person shooter) set on the beautiful tropical island of Panau where you assume the role of agent Rico Rodriguez. Your goal is to liberate the people of Panau from the reign of a dictator, who goes by the name of Pandak Panay. Throughout the course of the story you will become allies with criminal gangs on the island who send you out on missions in exchange for information (and cash). Some of these missions include assassinating colonels and driving a pink limousine! Overall, I'd highly recommend this game to casual shooter players or people who just want to blow stuff up!

reviewText: ---NOTE: I HAVE SEVERAL HUNDRED HOURS ON THE PS3 VERSION OF THIS GAME, AND 60 ON THE MP MOD. I'M NOT REVIEWING IT WITH ONLY 4 HOURS OF PLAYTIME---\n\nJust Cause 2... where to start? This is arguably, for me, the ultimate sandbox game. Perhaps trumped only by Just Cause 3, which I am yet to purchase, however, have played. The game sees you attempt to overthrow the corrupt government of Panau. How do you do this, exactly? By blowing stuff up. That is your main objective in this game. Cause chaos. For me, the campaign was not too important. Is it good? Yes. Is it great? Perhaps not. However, the campaign seems to just be a passing fad, and, although the dialog is well written, it is not memorable. Just Cause 2, however, offers an expansive open world, full of immense posibilities, from military bases and airports, from the smallest of villages to the huge capital city, and don\'t even get me started on the graphics. Even now, this game, from 2010, trumps many games released today, and the fact that even fairly low end (by today\'s standards) PCs can run it, makes it a viable alternative to the likes of GTA V, which requires a relatively demanding PC to run. My advice to you: Buy this game, now. At just ¬£9.99, it is an ABSOLUTE STEAL! This game is great for people who don\'t have a great PC, or are just looking to try the series, not wanting to spend large amounts of money on Just Cause 3, or even those of you who just love blowing things up. FAN-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING-TASTIC. Oh, and, while you\'re at it, get the multiplayer mod. You can do all the same explosion-y things, but with your friends.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is a 3rd person shooter that looks and feels a lot like GTA and Saints Row. It's main trademark is the grappling hook, that can be used to pull yourself to objects far away or pull objects towards you.

Pros:
+ Vast environment with distances that feel realistic. Driving 10 kilometers feels like driving 10 kilometers in real life. Downside of this is that the world feels a little empty and repetative at times.
+ All the major weapon classes are represented and you can upgrade your gear.
+ Pretty good story.
+ Memorable character build and rich dialogues.
+ The local propaganda radio reflects on your latest actions, trying to cover everything up.
+ Playing a villain was served in a satisfactory, humorous manner, that suited the whole story.


Cons:
- Missions start to feel repetative very quickly, falling roughly into 3 categories:
1. Go kill everyone and blow everything up in a particular place.
2. Help some gangsters get to a fortified camp and protect them until they take it over.
3. Destroy something/someone in a limited timeframe.
- A few bugs like falling through a bridge or not being able to get out of a turned over car.

Verdict
It's not amongst my favorite games, far from it. Travelling the distances was a pain and the repetative missions got tiresome quickly. On the other hand, unleashing havok has a quality of it's own and the game surely has a ton of content to keep your hands tied for some 20+ hours.

reviewText:
This is a game that will knock you're socks off, constantly. The graphics are breathtaking even in 2014 (arguably better than some other games currently out on the market.) The game play is good, consistant, although, the driving feels like the roads are ice instead of asphalt, the bikes are my favorite mode of transportation. This goes on sale, OFTEN. If you feel like you don't want to shell out 3 dosh for this, you are missing out on a great opportunity to experience to explore one of the more expansive and beautiful open world games in the early dawn of this century. For those of you just buying it for the multiplayer mod, thats fine too. It's a must to get that mod with it, but you would be just scratching the surface. The modding community for just cause 2 is expansive. i reccomend that you take some time to check out www.justcause2mods.com. The mods are free and so is sign up. The campaign isn't really anything to write home about, same blockbuster action with some cheap thrills mixed in there.

If you are looking for an expansive open world game look no farther. Decent gameplay, amazing graphics and an all inclusive modding community make this one of the best games i have had the privileged experience of owning twice and spent countless hours on.

Bottom line: ITS WORTH IT. GET IT!

reviewText:
Just Cause 2, from what I've played, is one of the best takes on the one-vs-many concept - put an entire island country in front of a near demigod of a man, and put the results into code. In essence, it is an action movie turned into a game, and in the best way I've seen in my years. Irreprievably overpowered gadgets, an open world large enough to keep you constantly on the run, driving vehicles, flying vehicles, standing on top of vehicles, standing on top of flying vehicles, and a goal at hand: to free the oppressed people of a small, fictional island from the tyranny of their dictator.

Thinking about buying this game? Keep this in mind: You will never feel much satisfaction quite like leaping from an exploding building into a full-on skydive.

Good luck, soldier.

reviewText: This game is fun when played in short bursts...its fun to just run around blowing stuff up, but it gets really annoying if you play for an extended period. It crashes a lot, the controls for flying planes are incredibly awkward, enemy AI is obnoxious, story missions (both main mission and side missions) are really contrived and boring, and the physics for driving cars almost kills any fun you can have from then, which is too bad, considering how massive the map is, and how much fun it is to drive across. When you start going fast in pretty much any car, if you spin or drift just a little bit, you flip all over and fly a few hundred feet. When you hit any little bump, you get hurtled into the air and it happens again. So, basically, you can manage to ignore all these stupid things if you play for short periods of time...and it is worth playing...so much stuff to blow up, and a huge, diverse map...its just too bad it has so many obnoxious and frustrating problems.

reviewText:
So I bought this game not really knowing what to expect. When it just came out, someone said it was awesome. And I gotta say, I am not dissapointed.

The game lacks realism on certain parts of the game, for example the grappling and the infinite parachutes. It is those things that makes the game awesome. It is a bit hard to get used to in the beginning of the game, but once you are used to it, you are glad you have it.

This game as a third person shooter is also a succes. Again, a bit difficult to get used to the dualwielding/single wielding hotkeys. The dual wielding is awesome in the middle of fights, because if you use it correctly, you aren't out of ammo most of the time.

No game is perfect, neither is this game. The stronghold takeovers are pretty repetitive, there aren't many of them, but all of them are the same: same goals, same order of objectives. The only difference is the difficulty.

The missions are mostly unique. I really enjoyed most of them. Some of them take a long time because it is a long mission or because some of them are kinda difficult. The shorter ones are usually pretty easy: Go there, do this and you are done. But there is a nice variety of missions.

Overall, if you like third person shooters and or weird games, then I strongly recommend this game. I haven't play multiplayer yet, so I don't know how good that is.

reviewText:
Just Cause 2 is immense.  The gameplay of GTA but with a combat oriented missions.

If you love a secret agent themed story, the ability to use a myriad of weapons, boats, cars, bikes and places to cause untold destruction and havoc, this is the game for you.

One of the few games Ive spend 250+ hours playing, despite the repetitive gameplay, the action rarely gets boring.  The mission goals are coupled well achievements and together just keep you playing for one more mission longer.
Everything about the game screams quality, from the chessy voice-acting, the lush enviroment and settings, to the wonderfully rendered vehicles and characters.

This is not a serious game but, its full-bodied serious action is unique in the 200+ games Ive played.  An inperfect game, but definitely my favourite one of all time.

Unmissable!!

reviewText:
A brilliant version of GTA, huge variaty of vehicles, ranging from air to sea to land.
Really good and realistic graphics, best particle system I ever saw. Physics are appaling. Ragdolls are stiff, flop around when dead and fly back when shot by a machine gun. Vehicle wreckage is alright, but dissapears very quickly making it unrealistic.
The police AI are more dumb than in GTA. They give up easily and send helicopters even to attack you when you hijack a jet fighter. The map is big, full of secret bases.

Unlike other games, you have a parachute and grappling hook feature. If you're in a plane and you're high up you can jump out and skydive. And using the hook you can grapple onto different surfaces, enemies and vehicles.

Brilliant game, good graphics, bad physics and a unique grappling hook feature

9/10

reviewText:
This game is amazing. No doubt about that. At least technologically. Its a massive open world sandbox that is probably what michael bay would dream about at night. This game is more BOOM than story but thats okay. the ubsurdity is part of the appeal in my opinion.

What i really dont like about this game is just HOW big this world is. When you have to constantly travel, and it takes decades to get from point A to B even in a helicopter, then it just gets a bit boring. The fast travel mechanic is okay but i dont like how it just dumps you in the air above a village or something.

But the size is also awesome. nothing is close by, therefore the strange and diverse biomes actually make sense unlike a certin block building sandbox game that gives 10 year olds boners. The vehicle variety is fairly large, but if you have a helicopter of tank then u are just compleatly OP. Nothing can take you out if u just dont try to get hit by missiles.

So buy it and give michael bay a hard on, I really like this game and you probably will too if you can overlook insane travel times.
